awd_titl_txt: Processing and Distillation of Multi-Qubit Block Codes for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum computers, which make use of quantum mechanical effects to process information, may soon be able to solve a number of important computational problems much more efficiently than any standard classical computer.  However, quantum computers are difficult to build because they are very sensitive to quantum mechanical noise, or decoherence.  This project will develop new ways to overcome decoherence by using novel types of quantum error-correcting codes. Efforts to circumvent decoherence are important because quantum error correction may enable fault-tolerant quantum computing with practical devices.  This project will investigate ways to improve the efficiency of quantum error-correcting codes so that fewer physical resources are needed in order to implement error-correcting protocols.  This would allow significant quantum computations to be done on smaller, more reasonably sized, devices.  This project will also train students who participate in this research on fundamental topics in quantum information science, and this will help to prepare them for careers in academics or high technology industries.

Even with fault-tolerant designs, constructing a quantum computer in the near term is a challenge because fault-tolerance requires a large amount of overhead:  each logical quantum bit (qubit) needed by a perfect quantum computer could require thousands or even tens of thousands of physical qubits after being protected by codes.  This project aims to dramatically reduce the overhead needed for fault-tolerant quantum computers.  Instead of encoding each logical qubit separately, much more efficient codes are used that encode many logical qubits in the same codeword.  Computing with such multi-qubit codes requires new techniques, which this project will study:  logical teleportation, state distillation, and the development of different kinds of codes (such as quantum low-density parity-check codes), with different properties.  If everything works well, the overhead could be reduced to as low as a few tens of physical qubits per logical qubit.  This would allow nontrivial quantum computations by computers of a reasonable size.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum computing holds promise to dramatically increase our ability to solve certain difficult computational problems, especially the problem of simulating quantum systems, like chemical reactions or quantum field theory. Small quantum processors now exist, the so-called NISQ (Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum) machines, but they are too small at present to run more than a very limited class of quantum programs. We know, theoretically, that if the noise rate can be reduced, it is possible to scale up quantum computations to unlimited size using fault-tolerant methods built on quantum error-correcting codes. But the theoretical methods that have been discovered have a very high overhead, requiring dramatically larger quantum processors to reap the benefits of error correction.

This project aims to dramatically reduce the overhead of fault-tolerant quantum computing by using much more efficient quantum codes, that can encode multiple quantum bits (qubits) in each codeword and process them without decoding. The goals of this approach are to develop the techniques necessary to use this approach, estimate the expected performance and its dependence on the level of noise, and explore methods that can be used in the next few years as well as in the longer term, as technology improves. This approach to fault tolerance uses quantum teleportation of quantum bits within and between codewords to realize a full set of quantum gates.
In addition to this primary research on fault tolerant quantum computation, this grant also supported a number of side projects relating to other aspects of quantum error correction. In particular, it explored the possibility of continuous quantum error detection and correction, in which errors in a quantum codeword are detected and removed continuously, while they are happening. While this theoretical idea has been around for more than a decade, this project showed ways that it could actually be implemented experimentally. There was also work on quantum steganography, a technique for hiding quantum information in codewords by disguising it as noise.

As quantum computing moves from a theoretical notion towards practical technology, we must develop the ideas needed to support that transition, and allow quantum information processing to reach its full potential. This project is one contribution towards that goal, complementing the work of many others in the quantum information community.
